comments.commentBody: Once again the Republicans are making this election all about taxes.  As an older voter I know that they have been doing this forever.  They've got nothing else. It's all so predictable.  If they were serious, the would admint the Bush tax cuts did nothing to stimulate the economy, and that the tax breaks for the rich should be allowed to expire.  If we make them permanent, our nation's economy will go in the tank permanently.

I was on the wavelength with this constructor; only things I didn't know were WHAMMY BAR and JARED LETO. I always learn something.

I guessed HOT TODDY right off. We've been seeing a lot of ERLE and ALOE lately. At least no OREO.

Bonne nuit from the land of the beehive HAIRDO.

@MOL -- I will also wake up tomorrow filled with regret.  But on the infrequent occasions when I succumb to late-night temptation, the thought of being able to go directly to Wordplay in the morning helps keep my glass half full.  Hopefully KarmaSartre will be back out of the crate by then.

Blood and money do not mix - there's no way around it. Providing your children with a solid education including a college degree with no debt is completely adequate.

If professional investors/lenders are not interested in funding the business then you know from the start that the chance of success is small.

The most important lesson though is HIDE YOUR MONEY! If you live large and run your mouth about your financial position people are going to ask you for money.

This is a pair of dirty socks that is best laundered, hung out to dry, and folded... in private. Nevertheless... we simians seem to be overly interested in other simians laundry... dirty or clean.

This $$$ business within families is best kept exactly there... within the family. I notice that few wealthy families divulge their private finances... as it should be.

Despite ample resources to project and plan for the future, both the print and electronic media are struggling to survive.  The Chicago Tribune has received recent publicity for its lack of judgement.  Given the media's poor example, this article seems disingenuous and, even, vituperative.

The media has been harping, day in and day out, that the Republicans will win in a landslide.  The media  have been saying this since the first day President Obama took office.  It's a known fact that if something is repeated over and over, people beiieve it is true.  Gee, thanks, media.  Things seem to be getting worse everyday.

It is actually a great deal worse than that. In addition to loaning/guaranteeing 4.5 million for a high-end sporting goods store in a county where the medium family income is about $30,000, Mr.Deal has now no money for his OTHER children/grandchildren should they need it! Talk about an uncomfortable Thanksgiving. How could any business blow through that kind of money (even if it did have a viable business plan?) And that bad loan has been in part responsible for the bank failing and the rest of the taxpayers picking up the tab.

Yet Mr.Deal, in 2008 paid a measley 1% federal income tax, due to tax write-offs he won't disclose. Must be nice.

My family can always ask me for help for NEEDS, and I will give them everything. Wanting to start a half-brained business (when apparently your credit isn't good enough to get a loan yourself) is NOT a need. Mr. Deal does not seem to recognize that just because someone WANTS something doesn't mean they have to have it. He abdicated his responsibility to his daughter by saying yes.

I imagine if he wins election he will recoup his fortune very quickly, given his history.

You could probably have picked a better example than this.

Hear hear! to Robert in Washington DC - commenter #1.

It's better to raise one's kids to be hard workers, ambitious, and goal-driven, then to give them $$ when they can't figure out what to do to earn a living as an adult!

Far wiser idea to lend the kids the money for their house or for rental property. The kids pay interest & principle back not to a bank but to mom & dad, it is still deductable if it is for their home, and a piece of property has a real value that a speculative business will not have.  Mom and Dad get a better return on their money than they can get right now from a savings account.  The kids may eventually get the money back in the form of inheritance, too.  It's a win-win situation.

There are much more common, if related, stories than this one of multi-million dollar loans/gifts to adult children, and a pending governorship.

MUCH more common are the MANY stories of "boomer" (or just "pre-boomer) generations of the MIDDLE, WORKING class that are already retired or are in the process of modestly comfortable retirement, having lived in much more fortunate and hopeful times than their children and grandchildren; whom they now find in, sometimes desparate, need for help..

Those, pre-Reaganomics, times, of unions, good wages and defined benefit pension plans; and now having a home that is paid for and perhaps some substantial savilngs permitted by all this, have evolved until we now find ourselves undermined, and sometimes at new financial risk, by our love for our, much less fortunate, children.

In THEIR times of the "information age", when "credit scores" determine everything from how much your car payment is, to whether you can even "qualify" to rent a house or be hired for many jobs; of "student loans" to be paid forever; and when you only have, at best, a 401k "defined contribution" plan into which your employer does not contribute, if you are lucky enough to have a job; and where what one already has so greatly determines what one will EVER have...

I say give the kids EVERYTHING YOU CAN -- AND VOTE DEMOCRATIC!
Yeah, god forbid you should lose a dime to anyone, let alone something that you brought into this world. Gross.

I have borrowed money from family, for professional school, for my first home, for a lot I bought. And I have lent money to family. I paid back all the money lent to me for professional school ($10,000), my first home ($8,000), although some of the money I borrowed for the land was later turned into a gift, although I was still paying it off on a regular basis and had plans to fully repay it.

I signed agreements for the professional school and land loan, my father gave me a short term loan for the closing costs on my first home which I paid back within 3 months and we never signed an agreement.

The money I lent to family I did not require a signed agreement and I wasn't paid back but that family member had given me money prior for professional school and since for a wedding gift and as far as I'm conerned we are more than even.

While I know most financial planners advise against lending money to family, I can't imaging turning down a request, in an emergency, from anyone in my family. I guess if we had a deadbeat family member, I might turn that person down since I agree that bailing someone out time and again can turn that person into a dependent.

You can buy a small, lightweight travel size power strip with three or four outlets for about ten bucks.  If all the outlets are in use, just go up to somebody plugged in to an outlet and ask to share.  Big smile, turn a bit of charm.  I've never had anybody tell me no.
I carry one of the adapters that converts one outlet to three.  If I really need an outlet and they're all full, I can ask to share.

I was very surprised this summer to be unable to find any outlets at the Frankfurt Airport in Germany. (At least I couldn't find them during an entire overnight.) You can find outlets at the Pulkovo Airport International Terminal in St. Petersburg, Russia. Hurrah for Russian efficiency and customer service!

When I was traveling extensively, i carried two three-way plugs.  Six people could use two sockets, the load per transformer is very low, about 150 watts on a 1500 watt line, less for a netbook or phone.  Downside is when the plane was ready and five people were still plugged in.  I told the last folks to take them and make sure they share, sort of like Johnny Appleseed.
You ought to mention the Atlanta Airport has about three outlets (total) for the entire airport and has no signs and does not monitor their use. Ridiculous.
Truly the most critical issue of our time.

I usually travel with a power strip so if outlets are scare I offer to share the power cord. Great way to make friends on the fly. No disappointments particular when one is powering a laptop and other accessories such as phone, bluetooth, etc.

A modern laptop might use at most 2 cents worth of electricity per hour (2 amps@110 volts or about 0.2 kW-hr).  It's absolutely trivial and surely worth it to the airlines to keep the passengers pacified while waiting for late flights.

used an outlet at JFK and was told that I was wrong to do so, but was not punished. I feel that the airports have to change with the times and if they have to give up some sockets, then they can, after all, they have cut back seat room to an impossible width and trimmed food services so that we only pay for th actual ride at a premium. A socket help could make customers feel just that bit better about how they are being treated overall.

Suggestion: if you're worried that someone will occupy a power outlet for too long, bring along a small multi-plug. That way there'll always be room for at least one more person to plug in.

Can anyone estimate the cost of the energy used by people plugging in their portable devices, compared to the cost incurred by people washing their hands in hot water in the public restrooms, or using the electric blow-dryers to dry off afterwards? And what about those power-hungry flat-screen TVs?

Isn't it a good thing to invest in something that might be beneficial to society as a whole rather than just chasing returns?

I don't invest in gold. I hoarde it.

I own a little stock in a company that is working on finding a cure for cancer.

I have more (unrealized) gains from the gold, but I feel better about the investment in a company that hopefully will help find a cure for a nasty disease.

My next investment will probably be some sort of green technolgy.

Most long term academic and investment industry studies show that returns are comparable between socially responsible/green/ethical and 'conventional' funds. This debate only continues due to ignorance of the research!

For a listing of the major studies see my page at:
http://investingforthesoul.com...

I’ve been following ethical investing for over forty years.

Good luck and best wishes, Ron Robins
